channel.title: Introduction to Music Theory (notes, intervals, scales, chords)
channel.description:
YouTube culture -- and thoughtful, well-organized, well-spoken experts -- have given us amazing educational resources. This forum topic will focus on the fundamentals of music theory, which can be -- has been -- a thorny, difficult subject to approach.
But really, it's fun!
Here are a couple very good "Music Theory 101" suggestions, each running ~30 minutes.
* [Learn music theory in half an hour\.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rgaTLrZGlk0) (Andrew Huang) * [Music Theory in 16 Minutes](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_eKTOMhpy2w) (Guy Michelmore) * [Music Theory Everyone SHOULD KNOW \| Chords, Progressions and Keys](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=heAcV-kqKrQ) (Rick Beato)
And Music Theory 201 suggestions:
* [Musician Explains One Concept in 5 Levels of Difficulty](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eRkgK4jfi6M) (Jacob Collier, Herbie Hancock, et al., WIRED) * [What is a chord?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VR3o45Pwx9Y) (Adam Neely) * [Music Theory and White Supremacy](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kr3quGh7pJA) (Adam Neely) * [Why you should learn music theory \(Prescriptivism vs Descriptivism\)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=49alQj7c5ps) (Adam Neely)

item.title: Introduction to Music Theory (notes, intervals, scales, chords)
item.dc:creator: scottmoehring
item.description:
Great subject! I love Jacob Collier’s videos. His theory fluency makes me want to learn this because he has such fun with it. I never got over the hump. I can hum any tune, but I don’t know the notes or why they work together.

My favorite Collier video, where he attempts to express a semi-randomized list of 18 emotions that change in real time. Then he discusses why he did what he did.
